function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Articles focused on COVID-19, Spanish influenza, H1N1, and generic 'influenza' or 'pandemic influenza' increase the risk of propagating contagious diseases.","Impact":"Uncontrolled disease spread can lead to widespread illness, death, and overwhelming healthcare systems.","Mitigation":"Implement strict public health measures, vaccination campaigns, and international cooperation for disease surveillance and response.","Technologies":"Vaccines, contact tracing apps, remote healthcare technologies.","People":"General population, healthcare workers, and vulnerable groups.","Owner":"Public health authorities, governments, and international organizations."},{"Description":"Inclusion of multiple international contexts, including developed and LMIC contexts, increases the risk of global disease spread.","Impact":"Uncontrolled disease spread across international borders can lead to global pandemics and strain healthcare systems worldwide.","Mitigation":"Enhance international collaboration, data sharing, and equity in access to healthcare resources.","Technologies":"Global disease surveillance systems, data analytics for outbreak prediction, telemedicine.","People":"General population, healthcare workers, and vulnerable groups.","Owner":"International organizations, global health agencies, and governments."},{"Description":"Lack of explicit inclusion of equity considerations in the literature review may perpetuate health disparities and lead to unequal access to healthcare resources.","Impact":"Marginalized and vulnerable populations may face disproportionately higher risks of disease transmission and adverse health outcomes.","Mitigation":"Promote inclusive research practices, address social determinants of health, and advocate for equitable distribution of healthcare resources.","Technologies":"Health equity assessment tools, community health information systems, telehealth for underserved populations.","People":"Marginalized and vulnerable populations, researchers, and policymakers.","Owner":"Research institutions, policymakers, and healthcare providers."}]}
